journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Vision-based force measurement using geometric moment invariants

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, People’s Republic of China
2Center for Educational Technology, Jiangxi Science and Technology Normal University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: SG Wang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. Email: wangshigang@sjtu.edu.cn; hwhust@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article presents a new vision-based force measurement method to measure microassembly forces without directly computing the deformation. The shape descriptor of geometric moment invariants is used as a feature vector to describe the implicit relationship between an applied force and the deformation. Then, a standard library is established to map the corresponding relationship between the deformed cantilever under known forces and a set of feature vectors. Finally, a support vector machine compares the feature vector of deformed cantilever under an unknown force with those in the standard library, implements multi-class classification and predicts the unknown force. The vision-based force measurement method is validated for eight simulated microcantilevers of different sizes. Both regional and boundary moment invariants are used to constitute the feature vector. Simulated results show that the force measurement precision varies with length, width and height of cantilevers. If length increases and width and height decrease, the precision is higher. This trend can provide a reference for mechanism design of microcantilevers and microgrippers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Force measurement is an important and active research area in microassembly. It protects parts and grippers from deficient and excessive forces, which can result in wrong assembly position or even fatal damage.

The most common force measurement methods are implemented by microforce sensors including laser-based optical, piezoresistive, and capacitive sensors. A non-contact method was presented to compute forces applied on the cantilever by measuring optical beam deflection.1,2 A novel cantilever located two separate piezoresistors on both sides instead of implanting them into sidewalls. The method measured applied forces parallel and perpendicular to the wafer surface and provided nano-Newton sensitivity.3 Chu et al.4 designed a capacitive force sensor with an integrated displacement reduction mechanism that provided milli-Newton sensitivity. However, these methods are intrusive and expensive.

Currently, machine vision has been integrated into force measurement due to its advantages. It makes full use of microscopes and cameras already present in the microassembly workstation. In addition, it is non-contact and non-intrusive. Such conventional vision-based force measurement (VBFM) methods generally reduce the problem of force measurement into that of directly computing the deformation. They compare the change of image features before and after the load of forces, and accordingly calculate the deformation of cantilevers or grippers. Then, applied forces can be recovered by means of linear elasticity theory.

Wang et al.5,6 calculated gradient and logarithmic strains of deformed objects. Through the stress and strain relationship of elastic materials, Cauchy’s stress was recovered to estimate external forces.

Greminger et al.7,8 used the template matching method to figure out the contour displacement field of the deformed object and recovered applied forces using the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map. The method was applicable to linear and nonlinear problems. It achieved a sensor resolution of ±3 nN for the cantilever and ±3 mN for the gripper.

Anis et al.9–11 used two pattern recognition methods to compare the microgripper before and after the deformation and obtained jaw displacement. Then, finite element analysis was performed to calculate applied forces. Herein, the pattern recognition methods were normalized cross-correlation and zero-crossing Laplacian of Gaussian edge detection.
Reddy et al.12,13 presented a geometrically nonlinear model to solve Cauchy’s problem in elasticity and measured forces applied on the boundary of the elastic body using displacement data.
All of these VBFM methods calculate the deformation based on complicated mechanical models. Hence, these methods may cost a lot of computation time.

In this article, a new VBFM method is proposed to measure microforces applied on the elastic cantilever. The method not only has the advantage of previous VBFM methods, but also gets rid of complicated mechanical models. The statistical shape descriptor of geometric moment invariants is used as a feature vector to implicitly express the relationship between an applied force and the deformation. Then, the method reduces the force measurement problem to that of pattern recognition using a support vector machine (SVM) to classify the feature vector and to predict the applied force. To our best knowledge, similar methods have never been reported.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows: section ‘The relationship between an applied force and geometric moment invariants’ formulates the elastic model of the cantilever and infers general relationship between an applied force and geometric moment invariants. Section ‘Force measurement using SVM’ proposes a force measurement model based on SVM. Section ‘Results’ gives simulated results of measuring applied forces on simulated cantilevers of different sizes and discusses potential microscope image processing algorithms. The final section provides the conclusions and points out future work.

sec.title: The relationship between an applied force and geometric moment invariants
The mechanical model of an elastic cantilever
sec.p:
In microassembly, a gripper is generally modeled as an elastic cantilever, but the presented VBFM method is not limited to this model. As shown in Figure 1, according to Bernoulli–Euler law, the displacement solution is (1)y=Fx26EIz(3L-x), 0<x≤L where XYZ is a Cartesian coordinate system, y the displacement along Y-axis, F the force applied on the cantilever tip along Y-axis, E the material elastic modulus, Iz=(bh3)/12 the Z-axis inertia moment of the cross-section, and L, b, and h the length, width, and height of the cantilever, respectively. Figure 1.
The elastic cantilever under an applied force.

sec.title: Incorporating geometric moment invariants into the force
sec.p: A set of geometric moments can describe global shape characteristics of the deformed object under different forces. The (p + q)th order geometric moment mpq is defined with the monomial upvq as (2)mpq=∫∫u,v∈Df(u,v)upvqdudv, ,q=0,1,2,3,… where u and v are the coordinates in the image pixel coordinate system, f(u,v) an image intensity function to describe the gray-level of a pixel in the coordinates (u,v), and D the domain of f(u,v).14–16 For binary images in which the object is segmented from the background, the intensity function has only two values with 0 assigned to the background and 1 assigned to the object. Geometric moments of different orders show different spatial characteristics of the image intensity distribution. By the definition, the zero-order geometric moment m00 represents the geometric area of the object; the first-order ones m01 and m10 provide the intensity moment about v-axis and u-axis, respectively; and (m10m00,m01m00) is the object centroid.

If u-axis and v-axis are, respectively, parallel to X-axis and Y-axis, the origins of both coordinate systems coincide, and the image is binary, it follows from equations (1) and (2) that the relationship between the force and geometric moments with the order less than four can be expressed as (3)m00=bL (4)m01=bFL48EIZ (5)m10=bL22 (6)m02=11bF2L7420E2IZ 2+b3L12 (7)m11=11bFL5120EIZ (8)m20=bL33 (9)m03=639bF3L1060480E3IZ 3+b3FL432EIZ (10)m12=43bF2L82016E2IZ 2+b3L224 (11)m21=13bFL6180EIZ (12)m30=bL44 Hence, it can be inferred that geometric moments are a function of the applied force. Meanwhile, the (p + q)th order central moment μpq=∫∫u,v∈Df(u,v)(u-u0)p(v-v0)qdudv is invariable to image translation and can be expressed as a linear combination of mij, where u0=(m10)/(m00),v0=m01m00, and mij(0≤i≤p,0≤j≤q) is the (i + j)th order geometric moment; μpq is normalized to define the (p + q)th order scale and translation invariant ηpq, where ηpq=μpq/(μ00 (p+q+2)/2); and ηpq can be used to derive the geometric moment invariant gk (k = 1, … , 10), as shown in equations from (13) to (22).14–16 Therefore, geometric moment invariants are also a function of the force F, expressed as G=ϕ(F). Herein, G=(g1,…,g10)T is a feature vector composed of g1,…,g10 (13)g1=lg|η20+η02| (14)g2=lg|(η20-η02)2+4η11 2| (15)g3=lg|η20η02-η11 2| (16)g4=lg|(η30-3η12)2+(3η21-η03)2| (17)g5=lg|(η30+η12)2+(η21+η03)2| (18)g6=lg|η30 2η03 2-6η30η21η12η03+4η30η12 3+4η03η21 3-3η21 2η12 2| (19)g7=lg|(η20-η02)[(η30+η12)2-(η21+η03)2]+4η11(η30+η12)(η21+η03)| (20)g8=lg|(η30-3η12)(η30+η12)[(η30+η12)2-3(η21+η03)2] +(η03-3η21)(η03+η21)[(η03+η21)2-3(η12+η30)2]| (21)g9=lg|(η03-3η21)(η30+η12)[(η30+η12)2-3(η21+η03)2] -(η30-3η12)(η03+η21)[(η03+η21)2-3(η12+η30)2]| (22)g10=lg|(η30η03-η21η12)2-4(η03η12-η21 2)(η30η21-η12 2)|

Under the transform of image scaling, translation and rotation, the geometric moment invariant gk of the same object shape is invariable, while the geometric moment mpq is always variable. This characteristic is proved by the theory of algebraic invariants.14,15 In other words, the geometric invariant can stably represent the object shape, completely irrelevant to the object distance, the pan angle and the roll angle of the camera. Since the pose of the microassembly object usually changes, the invariant is more suitable to describe the object shape. That is also why the geometric moment invariant, other than the geometric moment, is used in many application areas of character recognition,14,17 image registration,18–21 etc. In addition, moment invariants with the order higher than three are sensitive to image noise, spatial quantization, and intensity quantization, which may decrease force measurement precision.16 So, only g1,…,g10 are used to compose the feature vector G and measure the force.

Moreover, regional geometric moment invariants of an image are calculated using the boundary and interior part of an object, while boundary geometric moment invariants are calculated using only the boundary of an object.18 Both regional and boundary geometric moment invariants are used as feature vectors and corresponding results are compared in section ‘Results’.

As to the computation algorithm of invariants, for an 8-bit gray image (f(u,v) belongs to a set of {0,1,…,255}) with pixel resolution of H × V pixels, first, use image processing algorithms to detect the object’s edge and region for calculating boundary and regional moment invariants, respectively; then, generate a corresponding binary image with 0 assigned to the background and 1 assigned to the object; finally, scan the binary image and compute image moments in discrete forms of mpq=∑u=1 H∑v=1 Vf(u,v)upvq,μpq=∑u=1 H∑v=1 Vf(u,v)(u-u0)p(v-v0)q, ηpq=(μpq)/(μ00 (p+q+2)/2) and gk.16

sec.title: The force measurement model
sec.p: Given the maximum force Fmax, the cantilever can bear without damage, the domain of (0, Fmax] is divided into such m neighboring sub-domains as (0, Fsub], (Fsub, 2Fsub],…, ((m − 1)Fsub, Fmax], where Fsub is the size of each sub-domain and Fmax = mFsub. On condition that each sub-domain is small enough to achieve satisfactory force measurement precision, the force F in the ith sub-domain ((i − 1)Fsub, iFsub] is considered to be F=2i-12Fsub in magnitude, where i=1,…,m. Hence, a standard library Ts can be established as (23)Ts={(G1 s,a1 s),…,(Gm s,am s)}∈(R10×A)m wherein Gi s=(g1,…,g10)T is the feature vector of the ith class, ai s a known force, R10 a 10-dimensional rational space, A={12Fsub,32Fsub,…,2m-12Fsub} a set of known applied forces, m the number of classes, and Gi s∈R10,ai s∈A,i=1,…,m. In other words, a standard library is established to map the relationship between known forces and a set of feature vectors. Finally, the problem of force measurement is reduced to that of multi-class classification. An unknown force F can be predicted by comparing its feature vector G with those in the standard library.
The force measurement error eF and precision pF are defined as follows (24)eF=|F-a| (25)pF=maxF∈(0,Fmax]eF wherein a is the prediction value of F and a∈A.

If the force is assigned into the correct class, eF obeys the distribution, as shown in Figure 2. In each sub-domain, the error on either side is large and the maximum is 0.5Fsub, while the error in the middle is tiny and the minimum is 0. However, if the force isassigned into a class neighboring to the correct class, the error belongs to (0.5Fsub, 1.5Fsub]. Figure 2.
The distribution hypothesis of force measurement error.

In Figure 2, each sub-domain is recommended to have 10 sampling points in order to describe the detailed curve of force measurement error. Theoretically, the larger the number of sampling points is, the higher the precision is. However, sensing the change of geometric moment invariants is on the basis of sensing the change of the object deformation. Hence, the number is constrained to edge localization precision of the object deformation. Subpixel edge localization methods include the geometric model method,22,23 the correlation method24 and the interpolation method,25,26 etc. The localization precisions approximately vary from 0.01 to 0.5 pixel. For simplification, a typical value of 0.1 pixel is chosen. Furthermore, taking into account the image space resolution and the maximum force the object can bear without damage, we can estimate the number of sampling points. The number could be approximately regarded as its maximum.

sec.title: SVM multi-class classification
sec.p: SVMs are especially suitable for this multi-class classification of a small sample size. The implementation isbased on binary classification. The commonly used one-against-one method27–32 constructs m(m − 1)/2 classifiers, where each one is trained on the data fromtwo different classes. Given l training data (G1,a1),…,(Gl,al), wherein Gi∈Rn, i=1,…,l and ai∈{1,…,m} is the class of Gi, the method solves the following binary classification problem28,33 (26)minωij,bij,ξij12(ωij)Tωij+C∑tξt ij,(ωij)Tφ(Gt)+bij≥1-ξt ij, if at=i,(ωij)Tφ(Gt)+bij≤-1+ξt ij, if at=j,ξt ij≥0

In equation (26), (ωij)Tφ(Gt)+bij=0 is an optimal hyperplane to separate the ith and jth classes by maximizing the margin 2/((ωij)Tωij) and minimizing the penalty term C∑tξt ij; ωij represents an optimal normal vector of the hyperplane; bij is a scalar; ξt ij is the training error; C is a penalty constant; Gt is a feature vector in the training set of the ith and jth classes; at is the class of Gt; and ϕ(Gt) is a function to map the feature vector to a higher dimensional Hilbert space. Each binary classification generates a decision function sgn((ωij)Tφ(G)+bij) to assign G in the ith or jth class, where G is a feature vector from the testing set.

Then, the voting strategy ‘Max Wins’ is used to implement multi-class classification. If the decision function assigns G in the ith class, the vote for the ith class adds one. Otherwise, the vote for the jth class adds one. Finally, the SVM predicts that G is in the class with maximum votes.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Images of the deformed cantilever under different forces are simulated by the cantilever tip displacement solutionof y=FL33EIZ. Set Fsub=1µN and F=0.5,1.5,…,0.5(2m-1)µN to generate a set of simulated images for known classes. Likewise, set F=0.1,0.2,…,m µN to generate a set of simulated images for unknown classes. Then, for each image, detect the edge and region of the deformed cantilever, compute the feature vector of geometric moment invariants as mentioned in section ‘Incorporating geometric moment invariants into the force’, and construct the training set for known classes and the testing set for unknown classes. Finally, LIBSVM,34 a widely used SVM software package, compares the feature vector in the testing set with those in the training set, assigns the feature vector into one of the known classes and obtains the corresponding applied force.

The proposed VBFM method is validated for eight simulated cantilevers. The material is assumed to be nickel alloy with elastic modulus equal to 207 GPa. In addition, the camera optical axis is perpendicular to XOY-plane and the space resolution is set to 1.0 µm/pixel. The method is implemented on a computer with dual AMD 2.11 GHz CPU and 1.0 GB RAM. Programming environments are MATLAB 7.0 and Visual C++ 6.0.
Both regional and boundary moment invariants are used to compose the feature vector and the influence on force measurement precisions is analyzed.

sec.title: Potential microscope image processing algorithms
sec.p:
A microscope image of the cantilever is assumed to be similar to Figure 3(a). The loader is fixed on a micro-displacement platform. By means of the platform movement in the vertical direction, the loader applies forces on the cantilever. In order to calculate geometric moment invariants of the cantilever, its edge and region need to be detected in advance. Potential image processing algorithms include the following.
Step 1: Laplacian of Gaussian (LoG) edge detection. The zero-crossing LoG edge detector35 looks for places where the value of LoG passes through zero, namely, the points where the Laplacian value changes its sign. Meanwhile, zero-crossings always lie on closed contours. Therefore, the detected edge is a binary image with many continuous curves of single pixel thickness. Figure 3(b) shows the LoG edge.
Step 2: Line detection to separate the cantilever from the base. The cantilever and the base are connected by a line. The algorithms of Radon transform36 and Hough transform37,38 are suitable to detect the line. Then, the cantilever can be separated from the base by deleting the left region of the line. Figure 3(c) shows the detected line.
Step 3: Object recognition. The edge generated by previous steps still consists of many continuous curves, corresponding to the cantilever, the loader, and the noise, respectively. They can be separately labeled by pixel connectivity of 8-connected neighborhoods. Then, by means of a priori knowledge about relative sizes of the cantilever and the loader, the cantilever edge is recognized. Finally, the cantilever region is obtained by a flood-fill operation of the edge.39 Figure 3(d) shows the final cantilever edge.
Figure 3.
A microscope image of the cantilever.

sec.title: Simulated results using regional geometric moment invariants
sec.p:
The simulated cantilever (L = 500 µm, b = 10 µm, h = 4 µm, F = 12.0 µN) under a force was shown in Figure 4. Regional moment invariants g1,g2,g3 slightly changed with applied forces, while g4,…,g10 rapidly changed, as shown in Figure 5. In other words, g1,g2,g3 are less dependent on applied forces. Therefore, g4,…,g10 were selected to compose the feature vector. Figure 4.
Region of the simulated cantilever. Figure 5.
Applied forces versus regional moment invariants.

The curves of theoretical and measured force versus displacement on the cantilever tip were shown in Figure 6. The theoretical curve represented F=3EIZL3y on the cantilever tip. The force measurement error was shown in Figure 7. The error in the region of [0, 0.5] corresponded to feature vectors assigned in expected classes, while the error in the region of (0.5, 1.2] corresponded to other feature vectors assigned in neighboring classes. Moreover, the maximum error generally took place, where the displacement was tiny. Force measurement precisions were different according to length, width, and height of cantilevers. They were 0.8, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, 0.9, 0.9, 1.2, and 0.9 µN, respectively. Figure 6.
Using regional moment invariants to measure applied forces. Figure 7.
Force measurement error using regional moment invariants.

sec.title: Simulated results using boundary geometric moment invariants
sec.p:
Edge of the simulated cantilever (L = 500 µm, b = 10 µm, h = 4 µm, F = 12.0 µN) was shown in Figure 8. Likewise, boundary moment invariants g1,g2,g3 slightly changed with applied forces, while g4,…,g10 rapidly changed, as shown in Figure 9. The change trend was similar to regional moment invariants. Aswell, g4,…,g10 were selected to compose the feature vector. Figure 8.
Edge of the simulated cantilever. Figure 9.
Applied forces versus boundary moment invariants.

The curves of theoretical and measured force versusdisplacement on the cantilever tip were shown in Figure 10. The force measurement error was shown in Figure 11. The error in the region of [0, 0.5] corresponded to feature vectors assigned in expected classes, while the error in the region of (0.5, 1.2] corresponded to other feature vectors assigned in neighboring classes. Also, force measurement precisions varied with length, width, and height of cantilevers. They were 0.9, 0.7, 0.9, 0.9, 1.2, 0.9, 1.2, and 0.9 µN, respectively. Figure 10.
Using boundary moment invariants to measure applied forces. Figure 11.
Force measurement error using boundary moment invariants.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new vision-based method has been presented to reliably measure microforces applied on elastic cantilevers. It is non-contact and non-intrusive, and may be conveniently used in the present microassembly workstation. Geometric moment invariants are used as a feature vector to describe the implicit relationship between an applied force and the deformation without directly calculating the deformation. Then, the proposed VBFM method reduces the force measurement problem to that of using an SVM to compare the feature vector with those in the standard library, to carry out multi-class classification and to predict the force.

Compared to other VBFM methods, the proposed method has two advantages. On the one hand, moment invariants in the proposed method are global statistical shape descriptors, while the cantilever deformation in other VBFM methods only describes local shape. On the other hand, the proposed method gets rid of complicated mechanical models and is not limited to the object shape.
The method used both regional and boundary geometric moment invariants to compose the feature vector and achieved similar force measurement results.

Simulated results showed that the force measurement precision varied with length, width, and height of cantilevers. If length increased and width and height decreased, geometric moment invariants changed more rapidly with the same applied forces, thus generally making force measurement more precise. This could provide a reference for mechanism design of microcantilevers and microgrippers.
Future work includes verifying the proposed method on microscope images and improving the force measurement precision.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study is supported by Natural Science Foundation of China under grant number 50875169.

ack.p: Sincere thanks go to Wenlong Li from Huazhong University of Science and Technology for discussion.
